speaker: Frasier
text: You know I've only got a moment, you know I've started a very exciting project.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you know this is KACL's fiftieth anniversary.  I did a little research and found out they used to specialise in live radio dramas.  So, I'm putting one on.  Dad, surely you must remember those?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh sure.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, people of dad's generation would sit around at night, listening to the radio absolutely mesmerised.

speaker: Martin
text: We were simple people.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, dad.  Anyway, I've spoken to the station manager. He's given me thirty minutes, to re-create the very first mystery KACL ever aired; "Nightmare Inn."

speaker: Martin
text: Oh don't tell me, I know: A bunch of people get caught in a storm, and everyone's wondering who's going to be the first one murdered.

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly, and I'm going to direct.

speaker: Niles
text: So, we can stop wondering.

speaker: Martin
text: What, don't you think your brother knows how to direct?

speaker: Niles
text: No, the trouble is he doesn't know how to stop directing. During our prep school production of "Richard III" he drove the entire cast crazy with his constant critiquing.  I seem to recall a delay on the opening night while our Richard chased Frasier around the dressing room, beating him with his hump.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that was just a little backstage horseplay to relieve tension.

speaker: Niles
text: You'll have an Orson Welles complex.  By the end of this week, you'll not only be directing, you'll have re-written the script and be playing the lead.

speaker: Frasier
text: I have no intention of performing in it myself.  The only re- writing I've done is simply cutting to get it down to thirty minutes.

speaker: Martin
text: [_reading script title:_] "Frasier Crane's Nightmare Inn."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_snatching script from Martin_] It's just a working title! [_exits_] _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Radio Station At KACL, Frasier has just finished his radio show.  However, he still needs to remind everyone about the upcoming radio play._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air:_] Well, that's our show for today, but let me remind you to tune in on Saturday night for KACL's presentation of "Nightmare Inn."  Just set your dials for goosebumps.  Till then, this is Dr. Frasier Crane reminding you that [_in a ghoulish creepy voice, which sounds down-right hilarious:_] you never know what's lurking in the shadows.  _He gives a ghoulish laugh, and carries on laughing when he switches off the air and as Roz walks into his booth._

speaker: Roz
text: Well, that should certainly comfort the woman who called in about her paranoia.  Listen, do we have a leading man yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, you could do it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh don't be silly, Roz.  It is a juicy part, it does call for a strong voice, but believe me, my hands are full.

speaker: Gil
text: [_enters_] Oh, Frasier, I've had a quick peek at your script and I think I'd be perfect as Bull Kragen, the brutish gamekeeper.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looks at Roz in disbelief_] You know Gil, I think that's just a bit too on the nose. [_Gil agrees_] But you know who you could play?  Mr. Nigel Fairservice, drummed out of the Royal Air Force under mysterious circumstances.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Frasier:_] With him playing it, they might not seem so mysterious. [_Frasier hits her_]

speaker: Gil
text: I'll take it.  After all, Nigel does have that divine speech in the second act about his boyhood in Surrey.  "Romping with his school chums in the fens and spinneys, when the twilight bathed the hedgerows like a lambent flame." Actually, I had rather a long peek at the script. [_exits_]

speaker: Roz
text: Gosh, we still have a lot of these supporting roles to cast.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well actually, I'm working on that.  You know, Jennifer down in accounting is married to a professional actor, who specialises in dialects.  I'm thinking of asking him to play six or seven of the smaller parts.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_entering_] Hey Doc, need one more for your play?

speaker: Frasier
text: Absolutely Bulldog, just as long as you promise to promote it on your show.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Actually I wasn't talking about me, I was talking about a friend of mine; Maxine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Does she have any experience?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Are you kidding?!  If she had a dollar for every minute she spent on stage... [_thinks_] Oh wait a minute, she does.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we do still have a part open for the maid, she only has one line.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Does it have any big words?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it's simple; [_acting:_] "Look out, he's got a gun!"

speaker: Bulldog
text: Maxine could knock that line right out of the park.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, OK, but you've got to agree to play a part too.  We still need someone for the sinister silk merchant.

speaker: Bulldog
text: OK, it's a deal.  Maxine is going to be so excited.  I gotta remember to pick her up one of those cute little French maid outfits on my way home from work.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's radio, Bulldog, she doesn't have to appear in costume.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Maybe here she doesn't!  _Frasier and Roz walk out of the booth and carry on their conversation as they walk down the hallway._

speaker: Roz
text: Well, we're getting there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Except the lead!  I haven't found anyone remotely qualified to play a wily old Scotland Yard inspector.  You know, you might be right, Roz, I'll have to bite the bullet and take on the part myself.  _They bump into Ian, a man who looks and talks exactly like an inspector._

speaker: Ian
text: [_takes pipe out of mouth_] Excuse me, Dr. Crane, is it too late to read for role of the inspector?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm afraid the role has already been cast. _Roz and Ian look stunned as Frasier walks away happy with himself.  FADE TO:_ **HAM RADIO** _Scene Three - Frasier's Apartment. Later, in Frasier's apartment, Daphne answers the door.  Roz, Bulldog, Gil and Mel the actor enter._

speaker: Daphne
text: Come on in.

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Gil
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, Gil, right on time.  We have to be on our toes tonight, we have a professional actor with us, Mel White, our man of a thousand voices.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, it's a huge pleasure.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mel's going to play Hans the German butler, both McAllister sisters, and Pepo the dwarf; a little man with a big secret.

speaker: Bulldog
text: The same guy's playing all those parts?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, he's also playing Bull Kragen the game keeper, and O'Toole the handy man.  Do you think you're up to it, Mel?

speaker: Mel
text: Just so long they don't all talk at once!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_excited:_] Isn't it lovely to be working with a professional! [_to Bulldog:_] Bulldog, where's Maxine?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, she's home with food poisoning, it's nothing serious. I think she just wrestled in some bad Jell-O.

speaker: Frasier
text: Never mind, she just has one line anyway. [_acting:_] Look out, he's got a gun! [_sympathetically:_] You think you might be up to that this evening, Daphne?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_sarcastically:_] I'll try!

speaker: Gil
text: Frasier, one of Nigel's lines seems to be missing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why yes, I had to cut the play by twenty minutes.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh yes, but that line so neatly defined Nigel's character.

speaker: Frasier
text: Saying "Gesundheit" after the butler sneezes?!

speaker: Gil
text: It shows he's a caring person.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's cut, Gil.  Learn to let go.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh very well, as long as I still have that delicious speech about my boyhood in Surrey.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes that's still in.

speaker: Gil
text: "Romping with my school chums in the fens and spinneys..."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes that one.  Thank you.  All right, I fear we might be running just a bit long still, so I've asked Daphne to time us this evening and also Noel hasn't rounded up all the sound effects yet, so I'm gonna have Daphne read those directions as well.  Now that's a lot of responsibility on you Daphne, are you sure you're up to it? [_She looks at him as if to say "I have some use"_] All right, start the watch. Stage direction.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sound of door opening.

speaker: Roz
text: [_with cheese in her mouth_] Inspactar, thank goddies cam.

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop the watch.  Roz, I have a line here that says, "when she opened her lips I caught a hint of some mixed exotic accent."  You will notice it does not say, "when she opened her lips cheese fell out". [_to Daphne:_] Start the watch. [_acting:_] This is a grisly business, Miss Thorndike.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sound of door closing.

speaker: Roz
text: [_exotic:_] I can't believe any of my guests could be a multiple murderer.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's easy for you to say, but my job is to suspect everyone.  Please introduce me to your guests.

speaker: Roz
text: [_exotic:_] This is the silk merchant, Mr. Wang.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop the watch.  What's your problem?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Wang?  You've gotta give me another name, I'll crack up every time I hear that!!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right, how about Wing?  That's a great old Chinese name.  Everybody change Wang to Wing in your scripts.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sound of people changing Wangs to Wings.

speaker: Frasier
text: From your line.  Start it.

speaker: Roz
text: [_exotic:_] This is the silk merchant, Mr. Wing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you see anything suspicious, Wing?

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_Chinese impersonation:_] Oh, me no looky, me go very by chop-chop.

speaker: Roz
text: Stop!  Chinese embassy on line one!  You can't say that.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, it's all right, I'll just adjust his dialogue later.  Start.

speaker: Gil
text: I'm Nigel Fairservice, inspector.  I was strolling in the garden when this dreadful tragedy occurred.

speaker: Frasier
text: Did anyone see you?

speaker: Gil
text: Several people.  Hans, the German butler.

speaker: Mel
text: [_German voice:_] Ja, I saw zee Gentleman.

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop! [_to Mel:_] That's wonderful, Mel.  But he sounds to me just a bit more Austrian than German.

speaker: Mel
text: I've done that accent both on Broadway and the London stage!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well perhaps they have different standards than I have. All right everyone, from the beginning once again.  Now let's try hard people, dig in!  And try to find the reality. From the dwarf's entrance.

speaker: Frasier
text: "And so the case was closed, and with a grateful shudder, I swore I'd never return to Nightmare Inn."  Stop.  Time?

speaker: Daphne
text: That's 32 minutes, 40 seconds

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn!  I'll have try to pin some more before we try again. All: Again?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, we're doing it until I'm completely satisfied, and that reminds me, Mel - I'm still not entirely happy with the second McAllister sister!  She doesn't sound spinsterish enough for me.

speaker: Mel
text: I see.  You also told me that my gamekeeper sounded too cultured, that my Irishman sounded more Protestant than Catholic, and that my dwarf was too tall.  Let me try Hans again, tell me how my German is sounding: "I Q-vit!" [_exits_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, wait!

speaker: Daphne
text: Sound of door slamming.

speaker: Bulldog
text: So what do we do now, boss?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not to worry, I have a plan. [_picks up phone_]

speaker: Roz
text: Oh yeah right, we're supposed to do this thing tomorrow night.  Where are you going to find an idiot willing to take six dialect parts unrehearsed?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_into phone_] Niles.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sound of ominous organ music indicating trouble ahead. _Everyone except Frasier chuckles along.  End Of Act One. (Time: 9:15)  Act Two.  Scene One - Radio Studio In the recording studio, Frasier is talking to Gil._

speaker: Gil
text: Oh there's your brother, how's he enjoying the prospect of playing six parts?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, he doesn't know about it yet.  He would have never agreed.

speaker: Niles
text: [_enters_] Frasier, you told me you were going to message the script to me this morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm so, so sorry.  I was tinkering with it till the very last minute, but not to worry.  Your natural talent will carry you through.  Look, take a look at this. [_they walk to Noel beside a bench with strange objects on_] Noel is going to give us a demonstration of the sound effects.  What have you got, Noel?

speaker: Noel
text: OK!  This is my door sound: [_opens fake door_] My thunder screen: [_sounds it_] Balloons for gun shots: [_bursts one_] And this plays various kinds of organ music: [_he demonstrates_] I've also got a gravel box, bells, a rain stick and a coffee thermos.

speaker: Frasier
text: What does that do?

speaker: Noel
text: It keeps my coffee warm.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_enters with Maxine_] Everybody, this is Maxine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello.  Welcome.

speaker: Maxine
text: Hi, I need a quiet place to work on my part.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, you got it baby, why don't you go up here in the booth. [_Maxine exits._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, work on her part?!  It's just one line.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Yeah, yeah, but she's got that condition.  What d'ya call it, it begins with a dis... dis- dis... er?

speaker: Niles
text: Distemper?

speaker: Bulldog
text: No, Dyslexia, that's it.  She's dyslexic.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you tell me that now.

speaker: Bulldog
text: No, no, no, hey, she'll be great.  It's me I'm worried about, I've got some serious butterflies going here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, you're on the radio all the time.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Yeah, but that's me being me.  This is acting, it's scary.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, that's all part of the thrill of the live performance. Butterflies in the stomach, sweaty palms, scratchy throat, pounding heart!  I suppose you have all of those?

speaker: Bulldog
text: I do now!

speaker: Roz
text: [_enters speaking with a numb mouth_] Phorry I'm late, Phaser, I just sphent two hours in the dentist chair.  An emergenphie, Ohh.

speaker: Gil
text: What is the matter?

speaker: Roz
text: Novocaine, he said it would wear opph by now.  I keep biteing my 'ip.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God, we've got sixty seconds.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't even know who I'm playing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't worry Niles, I'll just cue you as we go along.

speaker: Niles
text: Shouldn't I at least prepare a little?

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, listen, your natural spontaneity is your best asset as an actor.  What was it the Yale "Daily News" said about your Tartuffe?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, who remembers? [_off heart_] That I have the magnetism of Marlon Brando, the charm of Danny Kaye and the range of Laurence Olivier.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right everyone, places please.  _Meanwhile, Daphne listens to it in Frasier's apartment.  Eddie is also there on Frasier's favourite window chair.  Martin hurries in._

speaker: Daphne
text: Hurry up, it's starting. [_ominous organ music heard_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_radio:_] Good evening, this is Frasier Crane to welcome you to KACL's recreation of the original mystery theatre...

speaker: Daphne
text: I already know the plot, but I'll try not to blurt out the name of the murderer.

speaker: Martin
text: Great!  As a cop I hated it when people did that.

speaker: Frasier
text: In all my years at the Yard, I doubt I'd ever seen a fouler night [_thunder sound effect_] than that on which I was called out to investigate a double murder at the old inn on the moors. [_door sound effect_] The door was answered by Miss Carlotta Thorndike. [_door shuts_] Her face was unfamiliar and when she opened her lips I caught a hint of some exotic accent.

speaker: Roz
text: Inphector, ow!  Phank God you ca'.

speaker: Frasier
text: This is a grisly business, Miss Thorndike.

speaker: Roz
text: I can't beweive any of my guests cod be a... mopible mupuder.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's easy for you to say.  But my job is to suspect everybody.  Please, introduce me to your... no, no, never mind.  I know your guests by reputation.  This must be Mr. Wing, the silk merchant.  Did you witness anything suspicious, Wing? [_Bulldog freezes on the spot so Frasier covers_] Of course, the inscrutable and mute Mr. Wing, who wears a bell on his hat. [_goes to sound effects_] Did you witness anything suspicious, Wing? [_Frasier shakes bell_] No, eh?  I'll remember you said that.

speaker: Gil
text: I'm Nigel Fairservice, Inspector.  I was strolling in the garden when this dreadful tragedy occurred.

speaker: Frasier
text: Did anyone see you?

speaker: Gil
text: Several people.  Hans, the German butler.

speaker: Niles
text: [_Frasier cues him, speaking in German accent:_] Ja, I saw zee gentleman.

speaker: Gil
text: O'Toole, the gardener.

speaker: Niles
text: [_Frasier cues him, speaking in Irish accent:_] It �twas himself, and no mistake.

speaker: Gil
text: As well as Prudence McAllister.

speaker: Niles
text: [_Frasier cues him, speaking in an aristocrat lady accent:_] Yes, I was taking a breath of air.

speaker: Frasier
text: I tried to shake Nigel's alibi, but each witness was adamant. O'Toole!

speaker: Niles
text: [_Irish:_] Faith and it's true!

speaker: Frasier
text: Hans!

speaker: Niles
text: [_German:_] Ja, Voll!

speaker: Frasier
text: Miss McAllister!

speaker: Niles
text: [_old woman:_] Oh, please hence.

speaker: Frasier
text: There remained one suspect, whose whereabouts had not yet been established - Pepo the dwarf, a retired circus performer.  Exactly where were you when the murders occurred, Pepo?  _Frasier cues Niles, but Niles doesn't know how to do it.  He even tries to kneel down to appear he is small but realises it's radio. Frasier comes over to the sound effects bench and gives Niles a helium balloon to inhale._

speaker: Frasier
text: Pepo, where were you?

speaker: Niles
text: [_high voice:_] I was at the movies.

speaker: Frasier
text: At the movies you say, well one quick phone call can verify that!  _Frasier, still at the sound effects bench, pretends to dial the phone and pretends it isn't working._

speaker: Frasier
text: What's this?  Dear God, the phone lines have been cut. [_organ music_] Oh, we were really stranded.  Totally and completely isolated from any contact with the outside world.  _The studio phone rings and Noel answers it.  Frasier walks over and cuts the telephone cord._

speaker: Frasier
text: The phone lines have been repaired, you say? [_uses prop phone_] Hello?  Wait, they've gone dead again.  _Meanwhile, Martin and Daphne are listening to the end of the first act._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_radio:_] Who knows what other surprises this night may bring? [_organ music sounds, whilst Martin turns off the radio_]

speaker: Martin
text: I don't remember the plots of these things being so goofy!

speaker: Daphne
text: Mr. Wing wasn't mute last night.

speaker: Niles
text: Six different roles and six different accents, I have a mind to walk right out of here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'm sorry, Niles, but you're doing brilliantly.  Except your Hans could be a bit gruffer!

speaker: Niles
text: Don't direct me!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, you're right.  I'm just a bit more worried of being over time.  Gil, at the bottom of page fourteen, listen, after your shot just say "I'm dying," cut the rest.

speaker: Gil
text: That's my boyhood in Surrey speech!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I know.

speaker: Gil
text: You can't cut that, you can't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop whining!  We've got a play to do!

speaker: Gil
text: I don't care anymore.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right, please, quiet everybody.  Ten seconds!  Oh, Maxine, be sure to watch out for your cue and please, people let's pick up the pace. [_organ music and on air:_] Nightmare Inn, Act Two.  I was baffled, they all had alibis.  Suddenly Miss Thorndike pointed, her eyes wide with alarm!

speaker: Roz
text: There's somevon outside that phindow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why yes, Miss Thorndike, it appears to be... [_soft music plays sounding like a fairy, Frasier covers_] The ice-cream truck!  But never mind that, [_takes off leaves of paper_] suddenly the storm put the lights out. [_thunder effect_] And we were left with darkness.  Then a scream.

speaker: Maxine
text: Ahhhh!  Look out, he's got a nug!

speaker: Frasier
text: A gun!  A gun is what he's got.  When the lights came back up, a smoking gun lay on the table.  The maid lay dead, unable to name her killer.  Nigel Fairservice lay mortally wounded.

speaker: Gil
text: I'm dying!

speaker: Frasier
text: Poor man was gone.

speaker: Gil
text: Never again to visit the scene of my boyhood in Surrey, romping with my school chums in the fens and spinneys...

speaker: Frasier
text: Just then the lights went out again. [_gun sound_] Nigel Fairservice was shot again.

speaker: Gil
text: Only grazed me.  When the twilight bathed the hedgerows like a lambent...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_creates another shot_] The final bullet, blew his head clean off his shoulders.  All right people, let's try to keep calm although it's hard when the killer is among us.

speaker: Gil
text: [_walks over and makes the door sound effect_] Hi-ho, I'm Nigel's brother Cedric, who I haven't seen since my boyhood...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_creates yet another shot_] And so died the last surviving member of the Fairservice family.  _In Frasier's apartment, Martin and Daphne are still listening in disbelief._

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, I sure didn't see that one coming!

speaker: Gil
text: [_radio:_] Hello, I'm the ice cream man.  Years ago I went to school with Nigel Fairservice.  We used to romp in the fens and spinnies... [_gun shot_]

speaker: Daphne
text: This is turning into a blood bath.

speaker: Martin
text: This is why I prefer TV, you want to be able to see that stuff!

speaker: Frasier
text: By this time, I was more baffled than ever.  So I played a hunch; Hans, may I see your fingernails?

speaker: Niles
text: [_German:_] Vy?

speaker: Frasier
text: They seem a bit ragged for a butler!

speaker: Niles
text: [_German:_] Alvight, Alvight, I'm not what I appear.  None of us is.  I'm not a butler, I'm not even... [_turns page_] German?! [_normal:_] Sit down, inspector, you are about to hear a fascinating tale.  Each of us holds a piece of the puzzle to relate to you.  When we've finished you will know the full dark secret of "Nightmare Inn"!

speaker: Roz
text: Are thu thew with phat, Hans?

speaker: Niles
text: Be quiet, mother. [_organ here_] Mother and I moved here when I was a small boy after the... tragic death of my father...  _Niles carries on with the script whilst Frasier gives some very strenuous directions with some weird actions.  Niles eventually loses it._

speaker: Niles
text: I kept the pain of that loss buried deep within me like a serpent coiled within a damp... cave... [_throws script_] That's it!  I'm just going to take this gun off the table. [_takes balloons and bursts one_] Sorry about that, O'Toole, I guess we'll never hear your fascinating piece of the puzzle. [_two shots:_] Or yours, Kragen and Pepo!  Could the McAllister sisters stand back to back, I'm short on bullets! [_shot_] Thank you!  What was your name again, dear?

speaker: Roz
text: Miph Thorndike.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you. [_shot_] Ah, and also Mr. Wing. [_shot sound with bell fading_] And of course, one final bullet for myself so the mystery will die with me. [_shot_] Ha!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well then, that pretty much wrapped things up!  Hans was a mass murderer, who to the surprise of everyone, the case was closed.  And with a grateful shudder, I swore I never would return to Nightmare Inn!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we still have nine minutes remaining.  Perhaps we could have a little post-play discussion?  _Gil, Bulldog, Maxine, Roz and Niles look at Frasier as if to say "What the hell do you think?"  End of Act Two. (Time: 21:00)_
